trans-unit.source: Continuous delivery with Visual Studio Online in Azure
trans-unit.target: Continuous delivery with Visual Studio Online in Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to configure your Visual Studio Online team projects to automatically build and deploy to the Web App feature in Azure App Service or cloud services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to configure your Visual Studio Online team projects to automatically build and deploy to the Web App feature in Azure App Service or cloud services.

trans-unit.source: Continuous delivery to Azure using Visual Studio Online
trans-unit.target: Continuous delivery to Azure using Visual Studio Online

trans-unit.source: You can configure your Visual Studio Online team projects to automatically build and deploy to Azure web apps or cloud services.
trans-unit.target: You can configure your Visual Studio Online team projects to automatically build and deploy to Azure web apps or cloud services.

trans-unit.source: (For information on how to set up a continuous build and deploy system using an *on-premises* Team Foundation Server, see [Continuous Delivery for Cloud Services in Azure](cloud-services-dotnet-continuous-delivery.md).)
trans-unit.target: (For information on how to set up a continuous build and deploy system using an *on-premises* Team Foundation Server, see [Continuous Delivery for Cloud Services in Azure](cloud-services-dotnet-continuous-delivery.md).)

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes you have Visual Studio 2013 and the Azure SDK installed.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes you have Visual Studio 2013 and the Azure SDK installed.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, download it by choosing the **Get started for free** link at [www.visualstudio.com](http://www.visualstudio.com).
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, download it by choosing the **Get started for free** link at [www.visualstudio.com](http://www.visualstudio.com).

trans-unit.source: Install the Azure SDK from [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=239540).
trans-unit.target: Install the Azure SDK from [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=239540).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You need an Visual Studio online account to complete this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You need an Visual Studio online account to complete this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: You can [open a Visual Studio Online account for free](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=512979).
trans-unit.target: You can [open a Visual Studio Online account for free](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=512979).

trans-unit.source: To set up a cloud service to automatically build and deploy to Azure by using Visual Studio Online, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: To set up a cloud service to automatically build and deploy to Azure by using Visual Studio Online, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a team project
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a team project

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=512980) to create your team project and link it to Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=512980) to create your team project and link it to Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This walkthrough assumes you are using Team Foundation Version Control (TFVC) as your source control solution.
trans-unit.target: This walkthrough assumes you are using Team Foundation Version Control (TFVC) as your source control solution.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use Git for version control, see [the Git version of this walkthrough](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=397358).
trans-unit.target: If you want to use Git for version control, see [the Git version of this walkthrough](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=397358).

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Check in a project to source control
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Check in a project to source control

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the solution you want to deploy, or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the solution you want to deploy, or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: You can deploy a web app or a cloud service (Azure Application) by following the steps in this walkthrough.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy a web app or a cloud service (Azure Application) by following the steps in this walkthrough.

trans-unit.source: If you want to create a new solution, create a new Azure Cloud Service project,
trans-unit.target: If you want to create a new solution, create a new Azure Cloud Service project,

trans-unit.source: or a new ASP.NET MVC project.
trans-unit.target: or a new ASP.NET MVC project.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the project targets .NET Framework 4 or 4.5, and if you are creating a cloud service project, add an ASP.NET MVC web role and a worker role, and choose Internet application for the web role.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the project targets .NET Framework 4 or 4.5, and if you are creating a cloud service project, add an ASP.NET MVC web role and a worker role, and choose Internet application for the web role.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, choose **Internet Application**.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, choose **Internet Application**.

trans-unit.source: If you want to create a web app, choose the ASP.NET Web Application project template, and then choose MVC.
trans-unit.target: If you want to create a web app, choose the ASP.NET Web Application project template, and then choose MVC.

trans-unit.source: See [Create an ASP.NET web app in Azure App Service](../web-sites-dotnet-get-started.md).
trans-unit.target: See [Create an ASP.NET web app in Azure App Service](../web-sites-dotnet-get-started.md).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Visual Studio Online only support CI deployments of Visual Studio Web Applications at this time.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Visual Studio Online only support CI deployments of Visual Studio Web Applications at this time.

trans-unit.source: Web Site projects are out of scope.
trans-unit.target: Web Site projects are out of scope.

trans-unit.source: Open the context menu for the solution, and choose **Add Solution to Source Control**.
trans-unit.target: Open the context menu for the solution, and choose **Add Solution to Source Control**.

trans-unit.source: Accept or change the defaults and choose the **OK** button.
trans-unit.target: Accept or change the defaults and choose the **OK** button.

trans-unit.source: Once the process completes, source control icons appear in **Solution Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: Once the process completes, source control icons appear in **Solution Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for the solution, and choose **Check In**.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for the solution, and choose **Check In**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Pending Changes** area of **Team Explorer**, type a comment for the check-in and choose the **Check In** button.
trans-unit.target: In the **Pending Changes** area of **Team Explorer**, type a comment for the check-in and choose the **Check In** button.

trans-unit.source: Note the options to include or exclude specific changes when you check in.
trans-unit.target: Note the options to include or exclude specific changes when you check in.

trans-unit.source: If desired changes are excluded, choose the **Include All** link.
trans-unit.target: If desired changes are excluded, choose the **Include All** link.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Connect the project to Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Connect the project to Azure

trans-unit.source: Now that you have a VSO team project with some source code in it, you are ready to connect your team project to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have a VSO team project with some source code in it, you are ready to connect your team project to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com), select your cloud service or web app, or create a new one by choosing the **+** icon at the bottom left and choosing **Cloud Service** or **Web App** and then **Quick Create**.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com), select your cloud service or web app, or create a new one by choosing the **+** icon at the bottom left and choosing **Cloud Service** or **Web App** and then **Quick Create**.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Set up publishing with Visual Studio Online** link.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Set up publishing with Visual Studio Online** link.

trans-unit.source: In the wizard, type the name of your Visual Studio Online account in the textbox and click the **Authorize Now** link.
trans-unit.target: In the wizard, type the name of your Visual Studio Online account in the textbox and click the **Authorize Now** link.

trans-unit.source: You might be asked to sign in.
trans-unit.target: You might be asked to sign in.

trans-unit.source: In the **Connection Request** pop-up dialog, choose the **Accept** button to authorize Azure to configure your team project in VSO.
trans-unit.target: In the **Connection Request** pop-up dialog, choose the **Accept** button to authorize Azure to configure your team project in VSO.

trans-unit.source: When authorization succeeds, you see a dropdown containing a list of your Visual Studio Online team projects.
trans-unit.target: When authorization succeeds, you see a dropdown containing a list of your Visual Studio Online team projects.

trans-unit.source: Choose the name of team project that you created in the previous steps, and then choose the wizard's checkmark button.
trans-unit.target: Choose the name of team project that you created in the previous steps, and then choose the wizard's checkmark button.

trans-unit.source: After your project is linked, you will see some instructions for checking in changes to your Visual Studio Online team project.
trans-unit.target: After your project is linked, you will see some instructions for checking in changes to your Visual Studio Online team project.

trans-unit.source: On your next check-in, Visual Studio Online will build and deploy your project to Azure.
trans-unit.target: On your next check-in, Visual Studio Online will build and deploy your project to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Try this now by clicking the **Check In from Visual Studio** link, and then the **Launch Visual Studio** link (or the equivalent **Visual Studio** button at the bottom of the portal screen).
trans-unit.target: Try this now by clicking the **Check In from Visual Studio** link, and then the **Launch Visual Studio** link (or the equivalent **Visual Studio** button at the bottom of the portal screen).

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Trigger a rebuild and redeploy your project
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Trigger a rebuild and redeploy your project

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio's **Team Explorer**, choose the **Source Control Explorer** link.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio's **Team Explorer**, choose the **Source Control Explorer** link.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to your solution file and open it.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to your solution file and open it.

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, open up a file and change it.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, open up a file and change it.

trans-unit.source: For example, change the file `_Layout.cshtml` under the Views\\Shared folder in an MVC web role.
trans-unit.target: For example, change the file `_Layout.cshtml` under the Views\\Shared folder in an MVC web role.

trans-unit.source: Edit the logo for the site and choose **Ctrl+S** to save the file.
trans-unit.target: Edit the logo for the site and choose **Ctrl+S** to save the file.

trans-unit.source: In **Team Explorer**, choose the **Pending Changes** link.
trans-unit.target: In **Team Explorer**, choose the **Pending Changes** link.

trans-unit.source: Enter a comment and then choose the **Check In** button.
trans-unit.target: Enter a comment and then choose the **Check In** button.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Home** button to return to the **Team Explorer** home page.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Home** button to return to the **Team Explorer** home page.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Builds** link to view the builds in progress.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Builds** link to view the builds in progress.

trans-unit.source: **Team Explorer** shows that a build has been triggered for your check-in.
trans-unit.target: **Team Explorer** shows that a build has been triggered for your check-in.

trans-unit.source: Double-click the name of the build in progress to view a detailed log as the build progresses.
trans-unit.target: Double-click the name of the build in progress to view a detailed log as the build progresses.

trans-unit.source: While the build is in-progress, take a look at the build definition that was created when you linked TFS to Azure by using the wizard.
trans-unit.target: While the build is in-progress, take a look at the build definition that was created when you linked TFS to Azure by using the wizard.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for the build definition and choose **Edit Build Definition**.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for the build definition and choose **Edit Build Definition**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Trigger** tab, you will see that the build definition is set to build on every check-in by default.
trans-unit.target: In the **Trigger** tab, you will see that the build definition is set to build on every check-in by default.

trans-unit.source: In the **Process** tab, you can see the deployment environment is set to the name of your cloud service or web app.
trans-unit.target: In the **Process** tab, you can see the deployment environment is set to the name of your cloud service or web app.

trans-unit.source: If you are working with web apps, the properties you see will be different from those shown here.
trans-unit.target: If you are working with web apps, the properties you see will be different from those shown here.

trans-unit.source: Specify values for the properties if you want different values than the defaults.
trans-unit.target: Specify values for the properties if you want different values than the defaults.

trans-unit.source: The properties for Azure publishing are in the **Deployment** section.
trans-unit.target: The properties for Azure publishing are in the **Deployment** section.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows the available properties in the **Deployment** section:
trans-unit.target: The following table shows the available properties in the **Deployment** section:

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Default Value
trans-unit.target: Default Value

trans-unit.source: Allow Untrusted Certificates
trans-unit.target: Allow Untrusted Certificates

trans-unit.source: If false, SSL certificates must be signed by a root authority.
trans-unit.target: If false, SSL certificates must be signed by a root authority.

trans-unit.source: Allow Upgrade
trans-unit.target: Allow Upgrade

trans-unit.source: Allows the deployment to update an existing deployment instead of creating a new one.
trans-unit.target: Allows the deployment to update an existing deployment instead of creating a new one.

trans-unit.source: Preserves the IP address.
trans-unit.target: Preserves the IP address.

trans-unit.source: Do Not Delete
trans-unit.target: Do Not Delete

trans-unit.source: If true, do not overwrite an existing unrelated deployment (upgrade is allowed).
trans-unit.target: If true, do not overwrite an existing unrelated deployment (upgrade is allowed).

trans-unit.source: Path to Deployment Settings
trans-unit.target: Path to Deployment Settings

trans-unit.source: The path to your .pubxml file for a web app, relative to the root folder of the repo.
trans-unit.target: The path to your .pubxml file for a web app, relative to the root folder of the repo.

trans-unit.source: Ignored for cloud services.
trans-unit.target: Ignored for cloud services.

trans-unit.source: Sharepoint Deployment Environment
trans-unit.target: Sharepoint Deployment Environment

trans-unit.source: The same as the service name.
trans-unit.target: The same as the service name.

trans-unit.source: Azure Deployment Environment
trans-unit.target: Azure Deployment Environment

trans-unit.source: The web app or cloud service name.
trans-unit.target: The web app or cloud service name.

trans-unit.source: If you are using multiple service configurations (.cscfg files), you can specify the desired service configuration in the **Build, Advanced, MSBuild arguments** setting.
trans-unit.target: If you are using multiple service configurations (.cscfg files), you can specify the desired service configuration in the **Build, Advanced, MSBuild arguments** setting.

trans-unit.source: For example, to use ServiceConfiguration.Test.cscfg, set MSBuild arguments line option `/p:TargetProfile=Test`.
trans-unit.target: For example, to use ServiceConfiguration.Test.cscfg, set MSBuild arguments line option `/p:TargetProfile=Test`.

trans-unit.source: By this time, your build should be completed successfully.
trans-unit.target: By this time, your build should be completed successfully.

trans-unit.source: If you double-click the build name, Visual Studio shows a **Build Summary**, including any test results from associated unit test projects.
trans-unit.target: If you double-click the build name, Visual Studio shows a **Build Summary**, including any test results from associated unit test projects.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com), you can view the associated deployment on the **Deployments** tab when the staging environment is selected.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com), you can view the associated deployment on the **Deployments** tab when the staging environment is selected.

trans-unit.source: Browse to your site's URL.
trans-unit.target: Browse to your site's URL.

trans-unit.source: For a web app, just click the **Browse** button on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: For a web app, just click the **Browse** button on the command bar.

trans-unit.source: For a cloud service, choose the URL in the **Quick Glance** section of the **Dashboard** page that shows the Staging environment for a cloud service.
trans-unit.target: For a cloud service, choose the URL in the **Quick Glance** section of the **Dashboard** page that shows the Staging environment for a cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Deployments from continuous integration for cloud services are published to the Staging environment by default.
trans-unit.target: Deployments from continuous integration for cloud services are published to the Staging environment by default.

trans-unit.source: You can change this by setting the **Alternate Cloud Service Environment** property to **Production**.
trans-unit.target: You can change this by setting the **Alternate Cloud Service Environment** property to **Production**.

trans-unit.source: This screenshot shows where the site URL is on the cloud service's dashboard page.
trans-unit.target: This screenshot shows where the site URL is on the cloud service's dashboard page.

trans-unit.source: A new browser tab will open to reveal your running site.
trans-unit.target: A new browser tab will open to reveal your running site.

trans-unit.source: For cloud services, if you make other changes to your project, you trigger more builds, and you will accumulate multiple deployments.
trans-unit.target: For cloud services, if you make other changes to your project, you trigger more builds, and you will accumulate multiple deployments.

trans-unit.source: The latest one marked as Active.
trans-unit.target: The latest one marked as Active.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Redeploy an earlier build
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Redeploy an earlier build

trans-unit.source: This step applies to cloud services and is optional.
trans-unit.target: This step applies to cloud services and is optional.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure management portal, choose an earlier deployment and then choose the **Redeploy** button to rewind your site to an earlier check-in.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure management portal, choose an earlier deployment and then choose the **Redeploy** button to rewind your site to an earlier check-in.

trans-unit.source: Note that this will trigger a new build in TFS and create a new entry in your deployment history.
trans-unit.target: Note that this will trigger a new build in TFS and create a new entry in your deployment history.

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Change the Production deployment
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Change the Production deployment

trans-unit.source: This step applies only to cloud services, not web apps.
trans-unit.target: This step applies only to cloud services, not web apps.

trans-unit.source: When you are ready, you can promote the Staging environment to the production environment by choosing the **Swap** button in the management portal.
trans-unit.target: When you are ready, you can promote the Staging environment to the production environment by choosing the **Swap** button in the management portal.

trans-unit.source: The newly deployed Staging environment is promoted to Production, and the previous Production environment, if any, becomes a Staging environment.
trans-unit.target: The newly deployed Staging environment is promoted to Production, and the previous Production environment, if any, becomes a Staging environment.

trans-unit.source: The Active deployment may be different for the Production and Staging environments, but the deployment history of recent builds is the same regardless of environment.
trans-unit.target: The Active deployment may be different for the Production and Staging environments, but the deployment history of recent builds is the same regardless of environment.

trans-unit.source: Step 7: Run unit tests
trans-unit.target: Step 7: Run unit tests

trans-unit.source: This step applies only to web apps, not cloud services.
trans-unit.target: This step applies only to web apps, not cloud services.

trans-unit.source: To put a quality gate on your deployment, you can run unit tests and if they fail, you can stop the deployment.
trans-unit.target: To put a quality gate on your deployment, you can run unit tests and if they fail, you can stop the deployment.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, add a unit test project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, add a unit test project.

trans-unit.source: Add project references to the project you want to test.
trans-unit.target: Add project references to the project you want to test.

trans-unit.source: Add some unit tests.
trans-unit.target: Add some unit tests.

trans-unit.source: To get started, try a dummy test that will always pass.
trans-unit.target: To get started, try a dummy test that will always pass.

trans-unit.source: Edit the build definition, choose the **Process** tab, and expand the **Test** node.
trans-unit.target: Edit the build definition, choose the **Process** tab, and expand the **Test** node.

trans-unit.source: Set the **Fail build on test failure** to True.
trans-unit.target: Set the **Fail build on test failure** to True.

trans-unit.source: This means that the deployment won't occur unless the tests pass.
trans-unit.target: This means that the deployment won't occur unless the tests pass.

trans-unit.source: Queue a new build.
trans-unit.target: Queue a new build.

trans-unit.source: While the build is proceeding, check on its progress.
trans-unit.target: While the build is proceeding, check on its progress.

trans-unit.source: When the build is done, check the test results.
trans-unit.target: When the build is done, check the test results.

trans-unit.source: Try creating a test that will fail.
trans-unit.target: Try creating a test that will fail.

trans-unit.source: Add a new test by copying the first one, rename it, and comment out the line of code that states NotImplementedException is an expected exception.
trans-unit.target: Add a new test by copying the first one, rename it, and comment out the line of code that states NotImplementedException is an expected exception.

trans-unit.source: Check in the change to queue a new build.
trans-unit.target: Check in the change to queue a new build.

trans-unit.source: View the test results to see details about the failure.
trans-unit.target: View the test results to see details about the failure.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: For more about unit testing in Visual Studio Online, see [Run unit tests in your build](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=510474).
trans-unit.target: For more about unit testing in Visual Studio Online, see [Run unit tests in your build](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=510474).

trans-unit.source: If you're using Git, see [Share your code in Git](http://www.visualstudio.com/get-started/share-your-code-in-git-vs.aspx) and [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](../web-sites-publish-source-control.md).
trans-unit.target: If you're using Git, see [Share your code in Git](http://www.visualstudio.com/get-started/share-your-code-in-git-vs.aspx) and [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](../web-sites-publish-source-control.md).

trans-unit.source: For more information about Visual Studio Online, see [Visual Studio Online](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=253861).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Visual Studio Online, see [Visual Studio Online](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=253861).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
